title: 104_hr883
content: The Act may be cited as the "Free Trade With Cuba Act". It includes findings related to the Act. The Congress finds that the embargo on trade with Cuba is counterproductive and no longer necessary, as Cuba is no longer a threat. The United States should promote democratic change in Cuba through trade, commerce, travel, and communication. The United States should promote democratic change in Cuba through trade, commerce, travel, communication, and exchanges in various fields. SEC. 3. REMOVAL OF PROVISIONS RESTRICTING TRADE AND OTHER RELATIONS WITH CUBA. The text chunk discusses the repeal of certain authorities related to trade with Cuba, including the removal of export prohibitions. The Act repeals export controls on Cuba under the Export Administration Act of 1979 and grants the President authority to impose new restrictions under different acts in case of a national emergency. The Cuban Democracy Act (title XVII of Public Law 102-484) is repealed, and the denial of foreign tax credit with respect to Cuba is terminated. This change will take effect 60 days after the enactment of this amendment. SEC. 4 authorizes common carriers to install, maintain, and repair telecommunications equipment in Cuba and provide services between the US and Cuba, including upgrades. SEC. 5 pertains to travel. SEC. 5 allows for unrestricted travel to and from Cuba for US citizens and residents, including transactions related to travel. This includes normal banking transactions involving foreign currency. The United States Postal Service will establish direct mail service to and from Cuba, utilizing charter providers if necessary. The President is urged to negotiate with Cuba to settle U.S. nationals' property claims and protect human rights. The Act will take effect 60 days after its enactment.
